Title of Policy: City of Vancouver Embodied Carbon Guidelines
Description: Buildings in Vancouver must calculate the embodied carbon of a proposed design to show compliance.
Covered Material(s): Concrete, Insulation, Windows and Glazing, Rebar, Steel, Aluminum, Wood
Covered Applications: Part 3 Buildings: exceeding 600 m^2 in building area, or exceeding 3 stories; new buildings or major additions
Target: 40% reduction in embodied carbon in construction
Compliance Mechanism: whole buiding LCA, Type III EPD
Threshold Methodology: Survey of 2017-2023 embodied carbon submissions data
Disclosure Specificity: Project; Product -- industry or product-specific, depends on material
Source(s): City of Vancouver. (2023). Embodied carbon guidelines (Version 1.0). https://vancouver.ca/files/cov/embodied-carbon-guidelines.pdf

Description: Under Executive Directive No. 25, the Los Angeles, the Mayor's office delegated to the LA General Services Department that all new municipal-owned buildings or major rennovations be designed to reach carbon neutrality by 2030; the Mayor's office also directs the Bureau of Engineering to adopt the Buy Clean California Act Guidelines
Covered Material(s): Hot-Rolled Structural Steel, Hollow structural sections, steel plate, rebar, flat glass, light-density mineral wood board insulation, heavy-density mineral wood board insulation
Target: Carbon neutrality for new and rennovated municapally-owned buildings
Compliance Threshold Unit: kg CO2eq, CO2eq, CO2eq, CO2eq, CO2eq, 1 m2of insulation at RSI=1, 1 m2of insulation at RSI=1
Required PCR: Part B: Product Category Rule (PCR) Guidance for Building-Related Products and Services Part B: Designated Steel Construction Product EPD Requirements, UL; NGA PCR for Flat Glass: UN CPC 3711, NSF International; Part B: Building Envelope Thermal Insulation EPD Requirements, UL Environment
Source(s): City of Los Angeles. (2020). Executive directive 25: Climate emergency mobilization (PDF). https://lacity.gov/sites/g/files/wph2281/files/2021-04/20200210executivedirective25.pdf
Notes: Noting "other" for methodology because adopts BCCA exactly -- don't want to duplicate BCCA

Description: Policy S12: Minimzing GHG emissions requires Whole Lie Carbon assessments (operational and embodied cabron assessment for A, B, and C stages; The GLA guidance on WLC assessments follows EN 15978 (the European standard for measuring building performance) and the 2017 RICS (Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors) Professional Statement: Whole life carbon assessment for the built environment - Policy S17: Reducing waste and supporting the circular economy (reuqires Circular Eocnomy statement to be submitted alongside all referable proposals)
Policy Subcategory: Climate Action Plan, Building Code Requirements
Source(s): Greater London Authority. (2021). The London Plan 2021. https://www.london.gov.uk/sites/default/files/the_london_plan_2021.pdf

Description: Committing to C40 declaration includes committing to approve at least one net zero emission (operational and embodied) flagship project by 2050 and to lead by example with municipal procurement. Budapest, Los Angeles, Mexico City, and Oslo have participated in the declaration
Target: 50% reduction in embodied emissions for new buildings and major retrofits
Additional Targets: 30% reduction in embodied emissions for new buildings and major retrofits by 2025
Source(s): C40 Cities. (2021). Clean construction cities: A roadmap to reducing embodied carbon in construction (PDF). https://www.c40.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/CLEAN_CONSTRUCTION_CITIES_101121.pdf

Description: The City of Austin Climate Equity Action Plan has a goal to reduce the embodied carbon footprint of building materials used in local construction by 40% by 2030 from a 2020 baseline
Additional Targets:
By 2030, All new buildings are net-zero carbon, emissions from existing buildings are reduced by 25%, and all natural gas-related emissions are reduced by 30%.
Community-wide emissions from refrigerant leakage are reduced by 25%.
The embodied carbon footprint of building materials used in local construction is reduced by 40%.
A community-wide water demand of approximately 152,000 acre-feet per year is equitably achieved.
Source(s): City of Austin. (n.d.). Austin climate equity plan. AustinTexas.gov. Retrieved November 27, 2023, from https://www.austintexas.gov/page/austin-climate-equity-plan#:~:text=All%20new%20buildings%20are%20net,construction%20is%20reduced%20by%2040%25

Description: Boulder's Climate Action Plan lists an ambitious target to embodied carbon reduction. Under their objectives to achieve Net Zero carbon in new construction, the city is targeting to achieve a 40% reduction in embodied emissions by 2031. Starting in 2023, Boulder requires all new construction to conduct an analysis of embodied energy of the project, providing subsidies to offset the costs.
Additional Targets: By 2023, all new residential and commercial construction will be built electric ready. By 2023, require all new construction to conduct an analysis of embodied energy of the project, providing subsidies to offset the costs. By 2024, stand up a regional embodied energy roundtable of developers, architects, and contractors. By 2026, average EUI of commercial construction will be reduced 60% compared to a 2016 baseline. By 2026, partner with other communities and community stakeholders to collaborate on purchasing low carbon building materials for all future city operations; 10-15% reduction for new buildings annual; Align with Buy Clean Colorado
Source(s): City of Boulder. (2021, June 8). Study session for June 8, 2021: Update on Climate Action Plan. [PDF]. https://bouldercolorado.gov/future-climate-action

Description: This policy requires that all new buildings are built to an emissions-neutral standard. Embodied carbon analysis is completed for new construction and ideas such as passive design strategies, well-insulated building envelopes, and the use of energy-efficient technologies like LED lighting are encouraged. All New Construction shall require Embodied Carbon assessments (From Carbon Leadership Forum)
Source(s): City of Edmonton. (2021). Climate resilience: Climate change adaptation plan (Report No. C627a). City of Edmonton. https://www.edmonton.ca/sites/default/files/public-files/C627a.pdf?cb=1740980247

Title of Policy: Amherst Climate Action Adaptation and Resilience Plan
Description: Amherst's Climate Action Adaptation and Resilience Plan under Beyound 2025 strategy aims to mandate embodied carbon analysis for new constructions and work towards setting regulatory thresholds including both operational and embodied carbon throughout the building life-cycle.
Covered Material(s): Cement, Steel, Brick, Glass, Gypsum board, Insulation, Flooring materials, Ceiling tile
Additional Targets: 25% below 2016 levels by 2025; 50% below 2016 levels by 2030
Source(s): Amherst. (n.d.). Climate action and resilience plan (CAARP). Amherst. https://kladashboard-clientsourcefiles.s3.amazonaws.com/Amherst/CAARP+Final.pdf

Title of Policy: Phoenix Climate Action Plan - Embodied Carbon
Description: Phoenix’s Climate Action Plan includes language to reduce embodied carbon. Phoenix is moving towards reducing community carbon emissions from buildings, transportation, and waste to move toward becoming a carbon neutral city by 2050.
Source(s): City of Phoenix. (2021). 2021 Climate Action Plan. City of Phoenix. https://www.phoenix.gov/oepsite/Documents/2021ClimateActionPlanEnglish.pdf

Title of Policy: Ann Arbor Resolution to Encourage and Accelerate the Use of Low Embodied Carbon Building Materials in Construction
Description: This resolution focuses on encouraging the use of low embodied carbon building materials in construction projects. It acknowledges the significant role of greenhouse gas emissions from the construction and operation of the built environment in climate change. The resolution directs the City Administrator to develop criteria for utilizing low embodied carbon building materials in building and infrastructure projects, provide an annual report on projects where these materials were used, develop and share resource materials on the City’s Planning website, and conduct public outreach about these materials.
Source(s): Ann Arbor City Council. (2022, April 2). Legislation text: AF360C43-55BC-4A97-9C2B-916153E5C666. City of Ann Arbor.https://a2gov.legistar.com/ViewReport.ashx?M=R&N=Text&GID=55&ID=4598872&GUID=AF360C43-55BC-4A97-9C2B-916153E5C666&Title=Legislation+Text

Description: The resolution requests the Honolulu city administration to consider using carbon dioxide mineralization concrete for all future city infrastructure projects utilizing concrete.
Source(s): Honolulu City Council. (2018). Resolution 18-283: Confirming the appointment of a director of the department of human resources. City and County of Honolulu. https://www4.honolulu.gov/docushare/dsweb/Get/Document-212511/RES18-283.pdf

Description: The Portland Design Overlay Amendment has updated the tools and processes for Portland's overlay and design review program. It includes points for low-carbon concrete and for using wood products for sustainabily managed forests
Source(s): Portland Bureau of Planning and Sustainability. (n.d.). Documents and resources: Council-approved ordinance documents and exhibits. City of Portland. https://www.portland.gov/ppd/planning/doza/documents-and-resources#toc-council-approved-ordinance-documents-and-exhibits

Description: TGS sets requirements for high-performance, new development in Toronto. V4 introduces voluntary tracking requirements for building construction and lanscaping materials, in addition to low level mandatory requirements through planning approval. Future versions are planned for 2025 and 2027 to require low emissions buildings by requiring compliance with highest tier, currently voluntary performance standards
Additional Targets: 2025 and 2028 new, stricter versions of Toronto Green Standard
Source(s): City of Toronto. (2022). Toronto Green Standard, version 4. City of Toronto. https://www.toronto.ca/city-government/planning-development/official-plan-guidelines/toronto-green-standard/toronto-green-standard-version-4/

Description: Berkeley Green Building Requirements require a 25% reduction of cement in concrete mixes and recognize fly ash, slag, silica fume, and rice hull ash as cement replacements; Also requires 100% of concrete and asphalt to be reused or recycled
Target: 25% reduction of cement in concrete mixes
Threshold Methodology: 25% reduction of cement in concrete mix
Source(s): City of Berkeley. (n.d.). Berkeley Municipal Code, Section 19.37.040. City of Berkeley. https://berkeley.municipal.codes/BMC/19.37.040

Title of Policy: Vancouver Zoning Variances for Mass Timber
Description: The amendment of Zoning and Development By-Laws in the City of Vancouver allows mass timber construction 7 storeys and higher
Covered Applications: Mass Timber-qualified buildings seven stories or higher
Source(s): City of Vancouver. (n.d.). Zoning and land use document library amendments. City of Vancouver. https://vancouver.ca/home-property-development/zoning-land-use-document-library-amendments.aspx#bylaw

Description: The Langford Low-Carbon Concrete Policy requires that all concrete supplied to City-owned or solicited projects, and private construction projects greater than 50 cubic meters, must be produced using post-industrial carbon dioxide (CO2) mineralization technologies, or an equivalent which offers concrete with lower embodied CO2.
Covered Applications: All Public Buildings, Private Buildings over 50 cubic meters
Source(s): City of Langford. (n.d.). City of Langford announces bold low-carbon concrete policy. City of Langford. https://langford.ca/city-of-langford-announces-bold-low-carbon-concrete-policy/

Title of Policy: Township of Douro-Dummer Sustainable Development Program
Description: Approved single family, detached dwelling homes will receive a rebate for 40 to 80% reduction in project permitting fees sould they reach a carbon compliance threshold or reach carbon neutrality, respectively
Target: 29% reduction in community sector GHG emissions
Source(s): Township of Douro-Dummer. (2020). Sustainable development guidelines 2020. Township of Douro-Dummer. https://www.dourodummer.ca/en/building-and-renovating/resources/Sustainable-Development-Guidelines-2020.pdf

Title of Policy: Marin County Low Carbon Concrete Code
Description: The purpose of this chapter is to provide practical standards and requirements for the composition of concrete, as defined herein, that maintains adequate strength and durability for the intended application and at the same time reduces greenhouse gas emissions associated with concrete composition. This code includes pathways for compliance with either reduced cement levels or lower-emission supplementary cementitious materials.
Source(s): County of Marin. (n.d.). Marin County Municipal Code, Section 19.07.020: Definitions. County of Marin. https://library.municode.com/ca/marin_county/codes/municipal_code?nodeId=TIT19MACOBUCO_CH19.07CACORE_19.07.020DE

Title of Policy: King County Strategic Climate Action Plan
Description: King County's Strategic Climate Action Plan's strategies related to embodied carbon are: - Strategy 4.2.2: Partner with King County cities on C&D recovery and reuse. - Strategy 5.2.2: Support the transition to a reusable wood market. - Strategy GHG 3.3.1: Propose Strong Green Building Codes in Unincorporated King County. - Strategy GHG 4.2.1: Code development through the Regional Code Collaboration (RCC). - Strategy GHG 4.3.1: Propose strong green building codes in unincorporated King County. - Strategy GHG 4.14: Manage King County capital portfolios to maximize GHG emissions reductions in operational and embodied emissions. - Strategy GHG 5.8.1: Specifying low-embodied carbon building materials in King County capital projects.
Source(s): King County. (2020). 2020 SCAP: Reducing greenhouse gas emissions section. King County. https://your.kingcounty.gov/dnrp/climate/documents/scap-2020-approved/2020-scap-reducing-ghg-emissions-section.pdf

Description: National life-cycle carbon limits on new buildings. Mandatory. 2023. When applying for a building permit and when completing a building, an initial LCA (applying for permit) and final LCA (when completing a building) assessing the building's overall climate impact must be documented and complied. There are stricter voluntary targets
Implementing Agency: Danish Transport, Construction, and Housing Authority
Covered Applications: All new buildings (LCA for under 1000m^2, thresholds for above)
Additional Targets: 10.5kgCO2/m^2 2027, 9 kgCO2/m^2 by 2027, for all building sizes
Source(s): Nordic Sustainable Construction. (2023, January). Denmark introduces CO2 limit for new constructions. Nordic Sustainable Construction. https://www.nordicsustainableconstruction.com/news/2023/january/denmark-introduces-co2-limit-for-new-constructions#:~:text=The%20new%20Danish%20requirements%20entail,per%20square%20meters%20per%20year.

Description: Procurement policy requiring  materials to meet or be below maximum GWP threshold to be eligible to be included in all GSA-funded projects
Threshold Methodology: "20% reduction from GWP (CO2e) limits in proposed code language: "Lifecycle GHG Impacts in Building Codes" by the New Buildings Institute, January 2022
Disclosure Data Repository: Email to embodiedcarbon@gsa.gov; GSA Project Management Information System
Source(s): General Services Administration. (2022, September). Low embodied carbon concrete SOW language. U.S. General Services Administration. https://www.gsa.gov/system/files/Low%20embodied%20carbon%20concrete%20SOW%20language-Sept%202022.pdf

Description: Royal decree in Belgium setting the minimum requirements for environmental displays on construction products and for the registration of environmental product declarations in the federal database
Application Type: All products on the market in Belgium
Source(s): Belgian Official Gazette. (2014, May 22). Loi relative à la protection des consommateurs [Law on consumer protection]. Moniteur belge. https://www.ejustice.just.fgov.be/cgi_loi/loi_a1.pl?sql=(text%20contains%20(%27%27))&language=fr&rech=1&tri=dd%20AS%20RANK&value=&table_name=loi&F=&cn=2014052234&caller=image_a1&fromtab=loi&la=F#LNK0005
Notes: Note that this is from a translated source

Description: Procurement policy requiring materials (Structural Steel and concrete reinforcing steel, flat glass, mineral wood board insulation) to meet maximum GWP limits as certified by an EPD to be eligible for inclusion in a state public construction project
Implementing Agency: California Department of General Services; California Air Resources Board
Covered Material(s): Hot-Rolled Structural Steel, Hollow structural sections, steel plate, rebar, flat glass, light-density mineral wood board insulation, heavy-density mineral wood board insulation
Additional Targets: 2025 and every 3 years, new maximum acceptable GWP
Compliance Threshold Unit: kg CO2eq, CO2eq, CO2eq, CO2eq, CO2eq, 1 m2of insulation at RSI=1, 1 m2of insulation at RSI=1
Required PCR: Part B: Product Category Rule (PCR) Guidance for Building-Related Products and Services Part B: Designated Steel Construction Product EPD Requirements, UL; NGA PCR for Flat Glass: UN CPC 3711, NSF International; Part B: Building Envelope Thermal Insulation EPD Requirements, UL Environment
Source(s): California. (n.d.). Public Contract Code - PCC Section 10100-10104: Article 5. California Legislative Information. https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displayText.xhtml?division=2.&chapter=3.&part=1.&lawCode=PCC&article=5

Description: The NYS Buy Clean Concrete guidelines implements S542A, signed into law as State Finance Law 135-d December 2021, effective June 2022. The law calls for the Office of General Services (OGS) to establish guidelines requiring the procurement of low embodied carbon concrete on projects deemed appropriate by the office. The Law is intended to increase the: use and innovation of low carbon concrete in state procurement projects. The guidelines below were developed with input from a diverse group of stakeholders in concrete and government procurement in the state of New York during Q1 - Q3 2023
Implementing Agency: New York Office of General Services
Covered Applications: State agency contracts exceeding $1 million that involve the use of at least 50 cubic yards of concrete
Threshold Methodology: 150% of the Eastern Region average GWP figures from the National Ready Mix Concrete Associations’ “A Cradle-to-Gate Life Cycle Assessment of Ready-Mixed Concrete Manufactured by NRMCA Members
Source(s): New York State Office of General Services. (n.d.). NYS Buy Clean Concrete Guidelines. New York State Office of General Services. https://ogs.ny.gov/nys-buy-clean-concrete-guidelines-0

Description: The MI Healthy Climate Plan is a comprehensive strategy developed by the Michigan Department of Environment, Great Lakes, and Energy (EGLE) to achieve economy-wide carbon neutrality in Michigan by 2050, with aggressive interim targets. The plan addresses the impacts of climate change in Michigan and outlines actions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, improve health outcomes, right environmental injustices, and create economic opportunities. The plan notes buy clean as a priority method for decreasing material carbon levels in buildings
Implementing Agency: Michigan Department of Environment, Great Lakes, and Energy
Source(s): Michigan Department of Environment, Great Lakes, and Energy. (2022). MI Healthy Climate Plan. Michigan Department of Environment, Great Lakes, and Energy. https://www.michigan.gov/egle/-/media/Project/Websites/egle/Documents/Offices/OCE/MI-Healthy-Climate-Plan.pdf?rev=d13f4adc2b1d45909bd708cafccbfffa&hash=99437BF2709B9B3471D16FC1EC692588

Description: Executive Order 22 is a procurement policy that requires all asphalt mix, concrete mix, glass, and steel manufacturers to submit an EPD for eligibility for New York State contracts above $1 million and above a material disclosure quantity At this time maximum emissions limits have not been set.
Covered Material(s): Concrete mixes, asphalt mixes, steel, glass
Covered Applications: New York state projects over $1 million, over a certain material disclosure limit
Disclosure Material Quantities: Concrete mixes: 50 cubic yards or more; Asphalt mixes: 16854 pounds (or 10 cubic yards) or more; Steel: 20000 pounds or more of rebar, 5000 pounds or more, other steel; Glass: 2000 square feet or more
Source(s): New York State Office of General Services. (2022). Executive order 22: Embodied carbon guidance. New York State Office of General Services. https://ogs.ny.gov/executive-order-22-embodied-carbon-guidance

Description: Requires Department of Transportation to establish by 2025 a program to reduce greenhouse gas emissions that assesses greenhouse gas emissions attributable to certain covered materials department uses in construction and maintenance activities for state's transportation system, conducts life cycle assessments for selected set of construction and maintenance activities and devises strategies for reducing greenhouse gas emissions
Covered Material(s): Steel including rebar, reinforcing steel and structural steel, hot-rolled sections, hollow sections, plate steel and cold-formed steel; Concrete, including ready mix concrete, shotcrete, precast concrete and concrete masonry units; Asphalt paving mixtures
Source(s): Oregon Legislative Assembly. (2022). HB 4139: Enrolled version. Oregon Legislative Assembly. https://olis.oregonlegislature.gov/liz/2022R1/Downloads/MeasureDocument/HB4139/Enrolled

Title of Policy: Washington HB 1103 Buy Clean, Buy Fair
Description: Buy Clean is a procurement policy approach that addresses embodied carbon in state-funded construction projects by incorporating low-carbon construction requirements into state purchasing, including requirements for the disclosure of EPDs for products used on state projects
Covered Material(s):
structural concrete, reinforcing steel, structural
steel, and engineered wood products
Covered Applications: Public construction projects larger than 50,000 square feet or building renovation projects where the cost is greater than 50 percent of the assessed value and the project is larger than 50,000 square feet.
Source(s): Washington State Legislature. (2021). HB 1103: House Bill 1103 - 2021-22. Washington State Legislature. https://lawfilesext.leg.wa.gov/biennium/2021-22/Pdf/Bills/House%20Bills/1103.pdf?q=20240201162252

Description: Procurement policy requiring materials (Asphalt and asphalt mixtures; cement and concrete mixtures; glass; post-tension steel; reinforcing steel; structural steel; wood structural elements) to meet maximum GWP limits as certified by an EPD to be eligible for inclusion in a state public construction project
Covered Material(s): Ashphalt and asphalt mixtures, cement and concrete mixtures, glass, post-tension steel, structural steel, wood structural elements
Source(s): Colorado Office of the State Architect. (n.d.). Buy Clean Colorado Act: Max GWP limits. Colorado Office of the State Architect. https://osa.colorado.gov/energy-environment/buy-clean-colorado-act/max-gwp-limits

Description: Singapore's Green Building Masterplan was updated in 2021 including the Building and Construction Authority's Green Mark certification scheme that includes language on raising energy performance standards and placing greater emphasis on other important sustainability outcomes such as designing for maintainability, reducing embodied carbon across a building's life cycle, and creating healthier environments for building users. The Green Mark 2021 scheme is aligned with the United Nations' Sustainability Development Goals.
Compliance Threshold Quantity/Range: 10% Reduction from baseline, 20% reduction from baseline
Source(s): Building and Construction Authority. (n.d.). Green building masterplans. Building and Construction Authority. https://www1.bca.gov.sg/buildsg/sustainability/green-building-masterplans#:~:text=The%20SGBMP%20aims%20to%20deliver,80%2D80%20in%202030%E2%80%9D.&text=The%20earlier%20editions%20of%20the,Singapore's%20buildings%20have%20been%20greened

Title of Policy: Canada Green Procurement Policy Standard on Embodied Carbon in Construction
Description: Inclusion in new construction products of projects over $10million and 100m3 must include EPDs of concrete mixes used so that the total kgCO2/m3 in the project is at least 10% below the industry baseline
Covered Applications: New construction or renovation above material quantity threshold; $10 million solicitations 2022, $5 million solicitations after 2024
Compliance Threshold Quantity/Range: At least 10% less than GHG baseline
Threshold Methodology: Regional Industry Average Environmental Product Declaration
Required PCR: NSF International Product Category Rule (PCR) for Concrete
Source(s): Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat. (2019). Policy on green procurement. Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat. https://www.tbs-sct.canada.ca/pol/doc-eng.aspx?id=32742

Title of Policy: Draft Green Public Procurement Strategy and Action Plan 2023-2027
Description: An update to the current Green Tender plan, this GPP strategy action plan will require the Irish government to publish GPP rules for public works projects, including the following of design guidelines for different materials used in the production of public and commercial buildings
Implementing Agency: Ireland Department of the Environment, Climate and Communications
Target: 30% reduction in embodied carbon in construction materials
Additional Targets: Support the deliver of emissions savings of 375 KtCO2 in public (and commercial) buildings and by 735 KtCo2 by 2030
Source(s):
Government of Ireland Department of The Environment, Climate and Communications. (2023). Draft Green Public Procurement Strategy
and Action Plan 2023-2027. https://assets.gov.ie/271900/967d9357-f76f-40be-a939-aaae7518f067.pdf
.

Description: CleanBC has a Roadmap to 2030, which among many goals, aims to reduce embodied carbon by using more low-carbon building materials, such as mass timber, wood-based insulation, carbon-absorbing concrete, and concrete made with lignin fibres from trees and other plants. To accomplish this, the government will develop a Low Carbon Building Materials Strategy by 2030 that includes a holistic approach to decarbonizing buildings, initially emphasizing public sector buildings, by 2030.
Additional Targets: Set targets for low carbon materials by 2030
Source(s): Government of British Columbia. (2020). CleanBC roadmap to 2030. Government of British Columbia. https://www2.gov.bc.ca/assets/gov/environment/climate-change/action/cleanbc/cleanbc_roadmap_2030.pdf

Description: The government is prioritizing the reduction of embodied carbon of the structural materials of major construction projects by 30% starting 2025
Covered Applications: All new buildings and major retrofits
Target: Reduction of embodied carbon of structural materials of major construction projects by 30%
Compliance Mechanism: Disclosure of embodied carbon of products through life-cycle analysis of major building projects
Source(s): Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat. (n.d.). Greening government strategy. Government of Canada. https://www.canada.ca/en/treasury-board-secretariat/services/innovation/greening-government/strategy.html#toc3-5

Description: The Rikjswaterstaat (RWS) is part of the Dutch Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management and responsible for the design, construction, management and maintenance of the main infrastructure facilities in the Netherlands. RWS states that suppliers that can prove using the SPP tool that their products offer substantial CO2 savings potentials will be prioritized in procurement
Implementing Agency: Dutch Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management
Compliance Mechanism: National Sustainable Public Procurement rating system
Source(s): Procuraplus. (n.d.). Public authorities: Rijkswaterstaat. Procuraplus. https://procuraplus.org/about-procura/public-authorities/rijkswaterstaat#:~:text=SPP%20IN%20RIJKSWATERSTAAT,mainstreaming%20sustainable%20and%20circular%20procurement.

Title of Policy: Finland Mandatory Green Public Procurement of Low-Carbon Buildings
Description: Finland mandatory green public procurement criteria are planned to be in effect in 2025 using Finland's Method for Whole Life Carbon Assessment of Buildings. Also currently has voluntary limits published
Implementing Agency: Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Environment
Source(s): Aalto University. (n.d.). 30_1541_1_PB. Aalto University. https://acris.aalto.fi/ws/portalfiles/portal/53964010/30_1541_1_PB.pdf

Description: All buildings over 100,000 square meters must submit a climate declaration starting in January 2022 in order to receive their building permit. Developers must submit data for modules A1-A5 in the climate declaration that is registered at Boverket in their database, The building's envelope, load-bering structures, and interior walls must be included in the declaration
Implementing Agency: Sweden National Board of Housing, Building and Planning
Covered Material(s): Load-bearing structures, interior walls, building envelope
Source(s): Einarsson, K. (2022). Limit values Sweden. Nordic Sustainable Construction. https://www.nordicsustainableconstruction.com/Media/637985265628454917/NCFC_2022_Limit%20values%20Sweden_Kristina%20Einarsson.pdf

Description: Requirements for all new buildings in France to have a primary  total energy use limit
Additional Targets: 15% reduction in building carbon emissions in 2025 compared to 2022
Source(s): Green Design Consulting. (2020, December 3). RE2020: New buildings regulation for French carbon neutrality by 2050. Green Design Consulting. https://www.greendesignconsulting.com/single-post/re2020-new-buildings-regulation-for-french-carbon-neutrality-by-2050

Title of Policy: Green Tenders: An Action Plan on Green Public Procurement
Description: The current action plan for green public procurement (GPP) recognizes the need for GPP in line with EU goals for 50% public procurement as green, and construction is recognized as a necessary avenue for public procurement, with wood specifically mentioned. This will be replaced by the Green Public Procurement Strategy 2023-2027 once it is passed
Implementing Agency: Ireland Department of the Environment, Climate and Communications
Source(s): Department of Public Expenditure and Reform. (n.d.) An Action on Green Public Procurement. https://assets.gov.ie/124710/90335b18-8d7d-4217-b2a9-dfc5ce01cd57.pdf

Title of Policy: Whole-of-Life Embodied Carbon Emissions Reduction Framework
Description: New Zealand framework for reduction of embodied carbon in buildings has the following steps which shall be forthcoming as developed by the Ministry of Business: 1. New public sector buildings will report Whole Life Embodied Carbon, 2. All new buildings will report Whole Life Embodied Carbon, 3. All new buildings will have to meet initial carbon caps. 4. All new buildings will have to meet intermediate carbon caps, 5. All new buildings will have to meet carbon caps to achieve net zero emissions for new zealand
Implementing Agency: New Zealand Ministry of Business, Innovation, and Employment
Target: Institute embodied carbon cap for buildings
Source(s): Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment. (n.d.). Whole-of-life embodied carbon emissions reduction framework. Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment. https://www.mbie.govt.nz/dmsdocument/11794-whole-of-life-embodied-carbon-emissions-reduction-framework

Description: The 2021-23 Biennium Budgets fund the creation of a database to track materials purchased for state-funded infrastructure projects and two large Buy Clean and Buy Fair pilot projects.
Target: Develop Pilot Study for Buy Clean, Quantify embodied carbon
Source(s): Washington State Legislature. (2022). Senate amendment 1080-S AMS FROC S3081.3. Washington State Legislature. https://lawfilesext.leg.wa.gov/biennium/2021-22/Pdf/Amendments/Senate/1080-S%20AMS%20FROC%20S3081.3.pdf

Title of Policy: No. 594: Leading By Example: Decarbonizing and Minimizing Environmental Impacts of State Government
Description: This executive order from the MA governor sets carbon neutrality goals for the state as well as requires state agencies to assess and implement strategies to mitigate ghg and other environmental impacts when planning for and executing projects relating to the design, construction, operations, and maintenance of state facilities, and the procurement of goods and services. All state agency new construction after July 2021 must certify to LEED silver or higher
Implementing Agency:
Massachussetts Department of Energy Resources
Division of Capital Asset Management
Source(s): Commonwealth of Massachusetts. (2021, September 16). Executive Order No. 594: Leading by example—Decarbonizing and minimizing environmental impacts of state government. Executive Office of the Governor. https://www.mass.gov/executive-orders/no-594-leading-by-example-decarbonizing-and-minimizing-environmental-impacts-of-state-government#:~:text=All%20agencies%20shall%20assess%20and,goods%20and%20services%2C%20including%20vehicles.

Title of Policy: State Of Wisconsin Clean Energy Plan
Description: The State of Wisconsin's Clean Energy Plan has a section dedicated to exploring low-carbon building materials procurement policies. This mostly consists of researching policies, conducting studies, developing a standardized method for evaluating and reporting embodied carbon emissions, and using EPDs.
Source(s): Wisconsin Office of Sustainability and Clean Energy. (2022). Clean energy plan 2022. Wisconsin Office of Sustainability and Clean Energy. https://osce.wi.gov/Documents/SOW-CleanEnergyPlan2022.pdf

Description: Minnesota’s Buy Clean Buy Fair law kicks off a six-year working group called the Environmental Standards Procurement Task Force that will provide recommendations to the state for purchasing cleaner materials in public projects, as well as dates by which standards need to be developed for different building materials
Covered Material(s): Carbon steel rebar, structural steel, concrete, asphalt paving mixtures
Covered Applications: New construction or rennvation larger than 50,000 square feet, New construction/reconstruction of two or more lane-miles of truck highway
Source(s): Minnesota Legislature. (2023). HF2310 - 2023 Regular Session. Minnesota Legislature. https://www.revisor.mn.gov/bills/text.php?number=HF2310&type=bill&version=4&session=ls93&session_year=2023&session_number=0

Description: The Quebec Wood Charter is a policy that encourages the use of wood for all publicly-funded infrastructure projects. As a result of this policy, the provincial building code was updated to increase the maximum height for wood structures from four stories to six stories and taller. It also requires developers of government-funded projects to consider wood as a material option by requiring a comparative analysis of GHG emissions for structural materials.
Implementing Agency: Ministry of Forestry, Wildlife, and Parks
Source(s): Ministère de l'Énergie et des Ressources naturelles. (2017). Plan d’action pour la mise en valeur de la ressource bois 2017-2020 [Action plan for the development of the wood resource 2017-2020]. Gouvernement du Québec. https://diffusion.mern.gouv.qc.ca/public/Biblio/Mono/2017/07/1193408.pdf

Title of Policy: Executive Order (EO) 20-01 State Efficiency and Environmental Performance
Description: Washington State's Executive Order (EO) 20-01 has a section that requires new facility construction be zero-energy or zero-energy-capable, which includes the consideration of "net-embodied carbon."
Additional Targets: Net Zero embodied must be considered in new projects
Source(s): Office of the Governor. (2020, January 8). Executive Order 20-01: State energy efficiency performance standard (SEEP). State of Washington. https://governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/exe_order/20-01%20SEEP%20Executive%20Order%20%28tmp%29.pdf

Title of Policy: Michigan Healthy Climate Plan; Buy Clean, Buy Michigan
Description: Subset of the MI Healthy Climate Plan focussed on procurement of low-carbon materials
Source(s): Michigan Department of Environment, Great Lakes, and Energy. (2022). MI Healthy Climate Plan. Michigan Department of Environment, Great Lakes, and Energy. https://www.michigan.gov/egle/-/media/Project/Websites/egle/Documents/Offices/OCE/MI-Healthy-Climate-Plan.pdf?rev=d13f4adc2b1d45909bd708cafccbfffa&hash=99437BF2709B9B3471D16FC1EC692588

Title of Policy: State Of Wisconsin Clean Energy Plan
Description: Subset of State of WI clean energy plan details the intent to set up carbon limits for procurement rules for low-carbon construction materials
Source(s): Wisconsin Office of Sustainability and Clean Energy. (n.d.). Clean energy plan - DML - Summary. Wisconsin Office of Sustainability and Clean Energy. https://osce.wi.gov/Documents/Clean%20Energy%20Plan%20-%20DML%20-%20Summary%20(1).pdf

Description: This law builds on the 2017 Buy Clean California Act, mandating the Air Resources Board to develop a framework by July 1, 2025, for measuring and reducing carbon intensity in building materials, targeting a 40% net reduction in GHG emissions by 2035. Key requirements of the law include life cycle assessments for new large buildings, Environmental Product Declarations from manufacturers, and the establishment of a technical advisory committee to support implementation, indicating a broader future strategy for low-carbon building standards in California.
Covered Material(s): Hot-Rolled Structural Steel, Hollow structural sections, steel plate, rebar, flat glass, light-density mineral wood board insulation, heavy-density mineral wood board insulation
Source(s): California Legislature. (2022). Assembly Bill 2446 (2021-2022). California Legislature. https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=202120220AB2446

Title of Policy: A.B.43: Greenhouse gas emissions: building materials: embodied carbon trading system.
Description: AB 43 is a California legislative bill aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions associated with building materials. It amends existing laws to establish targets and frameworks for measuring and reducing the carbon intensity of materials used in construction projects. The bill also introduces the concept of an embodied carbon trading system to incentivize emissions reductions in the building sector.
Covered Material(s): Hot-Rolled Structural Steel, Hollow structural sections, steel plate, rebar, flat glass, light-density mineral wood board insulation, heavy-density mineral wood board insulation
Target: 40% reduction of GHG emissions, Establishment of a embodied carbon trading system
Archived Version: California Legislature. (2023). Assembly Bill 43 (2023-2024). California Legislature. https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billPdf.xhtml?bill_id=202320240AB43&version=20230AB4392ENR
Source(s): California Legislature. (2023). Assembly Bill 43 (2023-2024). California Legislature. https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billPdf.xhtml?bill_id=202320240AB43&version=20230AB4392ENR

Title of Policy: H.B. 1282: Requiring Environmental and Labor Reporting for Public Building Construction and Renovation Material.
Description: The bill mandates that firms engaged in large public construction or renovation projects report environmental and health product declarations, labor conditions, and additional data, while also establishing a public database managed by the Department of Commerce for this data. It also sets up a Buy Clean and Buy Fair Work Group to promote the use of low-carbon materials and uphold high labor standards in manufacturing.
Covered Material(s): Concrete products, reinforcing steel products, sturctural steel, engineered wood
Covered Applications: Construction projects larger than 50,000 gross square feet
Source(s): Washington State Legislature. (2023). House Bill Report 1282 (2023-24). Washington State Legislature. https://lawfilesext.leg.wa.gov/biennium/2023-24/Pdf/Bill%20Reports/House/1282%20HBR%20CB%2023.pdf

Title of Policy: H.B.0261: Eligible Projects - Procurement of Construction Materials (Buy Clean Maryland Act)
Description: Requiring producers of any cement or concrete mixture used in the construction of an eligible project to submit environmental product declarations to the Department of General Services by December 31, 2024; requiring the Department to establish a maximum acceptable global warming potential for certain categories of eligible materials by January 1, 2026; establishing an Environmental Product Declaration Assistance Fund to support the development of certain environmental product declarations; etc.
Additional Targets: Reduce limits in 2029 and every 3 years after
Source(s): Maryland General Assembly. (2023). House Bill 261 - 2023 Regular Session. Maryland General Assembly. https://mgaleg.maryland.gov/2023RS/bills/hb/hb0261E.pdf

Title of Policy: Seattle Green Building Incentives (Priority Green Expedited)
Description: Construction projects can receive incentives for participating in different green building requirements including meeting goals for embodied carbon in building materials. Incentives include expedited permits, more leeway on zoning ordinances, etc.
Target: 100 clean energy in buildings and vehicles
Source(s): City of Seattle, Department of Construction & Inspections. (n.d.). Green building. City of Seattle. https://www.seattle.gov/sdci/permits/green-building

Description: The government announced that it will 1. work with industry to establish voluntary product standrads that businesses could choose to adopt to help promote their low carbon products to consumers, 2. Develop an embodied emissions reporting framework that could serve future carbon leakage and decarbonization policies and 3. carry out a further technical consultation in 2024 on voluntary product standards and embodied emissions reporting and continue to work closely with UK industry to develop these measures further
Implementing Agency: Department for Energy Security & Net Zero
Source(s): UK Government. (2023). Factsheet: Voluntary standards and embodied emissions reporting. GOV.UK. https://www.gov.uk/government/consultations/addressing-carbon-leakage-risk-to-support-decarbonisation/outcome/factsheet-voluntary-standards-and-embodied-emissions-reporting

Title of Policy: City of Emeryville Community Benefit Bonus Mass Timber
Description:
The City Council passed the first reading of an ordinance amending the Planning Regulations to add Mass Timber Construction as a community benefit eligible for development bonus points. Utilizing mass timber allows bonus points for projects making them more eligible for bonuses for height, floor area ratio (FAR),
and/or residential density
Source(s): City of Emeryville. (n.d.). Item 93: Mass timber construction. City of Emeryville. https://www.ci.emeryville.ca.us/DocumentCenter/View/14071/Item-93---Mass-Timber-Construction

Title of Policy: Boston Draft Net Zero Carbon Zoning Proposal
Description: Beginning in 2026, new buildings in Boston with 15 units or more, a minimum of 20,000 sq. ft., and additions of a minimum of 50,000 sq. ft. or more to existing buildings, will be required to meet a net-zero emissions standard (i.e. BERDO 2050 CO2e Emissions Standard). Buildings shall demonstrate net zero emissions every year through the compliance pathways in the Building Emissions Reduction and Disclosure Ordinance (BERDO). The existing BERDO reporting and regulatory framework will enforce the annual emissions limits established under zoning.
Covered Applications: New Buildings with 15 units or more, a minimum of 20,000 sqft and additions of 50,000 sqft or more to existing buildings
Source(s): Boston Planning & Development Agency. (n.d.). [Title of the document]. Boston Planning & Development Agency. https://www.bostonplans.org/getattachment/c63f67da-2877-4351-84de-067a1269846c

Description: The CALGreen 2022 Intervening Code Adoption Cycle (effective July 1, 2024) includes new embodied carbon provisions. The code offers three paths of compliance: building reuse, WB LCA, or a prescriptive approach similar to Buy Clean California but with concrete. The code applies to nonresidential buildings greater than 100,000 sf and school projects over 50,000 sf in both adaptive reuse and new construction projects.
Methodology: Reporting/Analysis Requirement, Product/Material-Specific Carbon Limits or Reductions
Covered Applications: Commercial buildings 100,000 sqft and larger and schools 50,000 sq ft and larger
Compliance Mechanism: Industry-Wide Type III EPD, WB LCA
Source(s): California Building Standards Commission. (n.d.) Carbon Reduction Nonresidential Existing Regulations. https://www.dgs.ca.gov/-/media/Divisions/BSC/03-Rulemaking/2022-Intervening-Cycle/Pre-Cycle/CCRC-20220908/2022-09-08-ITEM-2d-Carbon-Reduction.pdf?la=en&hash=8F76E51A9E7493BE882364537DE0518E87865FD2

Title of Policy: U.S. Department of General Services P100 Facilities Standards for the Public Buildings Service
Description: The GSA-owned buildings internal design standard now includes a requirement for all new construction and major modernization projects to target a 20% embodied carbon reduction by performing a WBLCA
Covered Applications: All buildings owned by the US DGA
Required Disclosure Standard: ASTM E2921's Standard Practice for Comparing WBLCAs
Source(s): General Services Administration. (2024). P100 2024: Facilities standards for the public buildings service. U.S. General Services Administration. https://www.gsa.gov/system/files?file=P100%202024%20Final%20%281%29.pdf

Title of Policy: New Jersey Low Embodied Carbon Concrete Leadership Act
Description: Provides CBT tax credit for certain deliveries of low carbon concrete and for costs of conducting environmental product declaration analyses of low carbon concrete for projecs which require the purchase of 50 cubic yards or more of concrete. Concrete is considered "low carbon" if it certified to embody lower carbon emissions as measured by GWP than the baseline for conventional (not stated what the baseline is)
Covered Applications: construction or improvement project that requires the purchase of 50 cubic yards or more of concrete
Source(s): New Jersey Legislature. (2022). Senate Bill 287 (2022). New Jersey Legislature. https://pub.njleg.gov/Bills/2022/S0500/287_I1.HTM

Title of Policy: Low-Carbon Transportation Materials Grants Program of Inflation Reduction Act
Description: On March 12, 2024, FHWA announced $2 billion available to fund low carbon materials that create less pollution by reducing the levels of embodied greenhouse gas emissions, including concrete (and cement), glass, asphalt mix, and steel. In FHWA's Low Carbon Transportation Materials (LCTM) Program $1.2 Billion is available to State Departments of Transportation (including District of Columbia and Puerto Rico) through a Request for Applications (RFA) to fund activities and projects that advance the use of low carbon materials and products. This RFA approach will allow FHWA to quickly provide reimbursement or incentive funds to states to begin eligible activities and incorporate low carbon materials on construction projects now. In the coming months FHWA will also make available $800 million to target non-State applicants, including metropolitan planning organizations, local governments or agencies, Federally recognized tribes, Federal Lands Management Agencies, and other agencies through a Notice of Funding Opportunity (NOFO). FHWA encourages non-State applicants to partner with states on applications and projects.
Implementing Agency: US Department of Transportation Federal Highway Administration
Source(s): Grants.gov. (n.d.).Low Carbon Transportation Matrials Program. Grants.gov. https://grants.gov/search-results-detail/356233

Description: Capital project agencies shall make their best efforts to incorporate low-carbon concrete specifications for all batch plant ready-mixed concrete used in capital projects and for concrete sidewalks, where such agency determines that such specifications are practicable and not preempted by State or Federal requirements. Capital project agency. In accordance with guidance from the Office, capital project agencies shall develop and submit action plans aimed at reducing embodied carbon in capital projects to the Office by October 1, 2023. Such agencies are encouraged to develop joint action plans.construction managers shall submit environmental product declarations (EPDs) to the Building Transparency database, a publicly available database of EPD
Compliance Mechanism: Type III EPD, Life Cycle Assessment
Source(s): New York City Mayor's Office. (2022, September 22). Executive Order 23. New York City Mayor's Office. https://www.nyc.gov/office-of-the-mayor/news/023-002/executive-order-23

Description: Government construction projects must contract from suppliers which are able to certify lower embodied carbon materials through either a NABERS Embodied Carbon 4-star rating or other low-carbon/avoided carbon specification (not detailed) starting July 2024
Methodology: Reporting/Analysis Requirement, Product/Material-Specific Carbon Limits or Reductions
Source(s): Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water. (n.d.). ESP policy reporting framework. Australian Government. https://www.dcceew.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/esp-policy-reporting-framework.pdf

Title of Policy: China Notice on Expanding the Scope of the Government Procurement Policy to Support Green Building Materials and Promote Improved Building Quality
Description: Starting from November 2022, the government procurement policy of supporting green building materials and promoting the improvement of building quality will be implemented in 48 cities (districts) including Chaoyang District, Beijing (including the previous 6 pilot cities, see Appendix 1 for the specific list of cities). Projects included in the scope of policy implementation include government procurement projects such as hospitals, schools, office buildings, complexes, exhibition halls, convention and exhibition centers, gymnasiums, and affordable housing, including government procurement projects subject to the Tendering and Bidding Law. The relevant cities may choose to implement some projects first, and gradually expand the scope based on summarizing experience, so as to achieve full coverage of the implementation of government procurement project policies by 2025. It is encouraged to include other government investment projects in the scope of implementation.
Implementing Agency: Ministry of Finance Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development Ministry of Industry and Information Technology
Covered Applications: government procurement projects such as hospitals, schools, office buildings, complexes, exhibition halls, convention and exhibition centers, gymnasiums, and affordable housing, including government procurement projects subject to the Tendering and Bidding Law
Source(s): State Council of the People's Republic of China. (2022, October 25). Notice on expanding the scope of government procurement to support green building materials and promote the improvement of building quality. The State Council of the People's Republic of China. https://www.gov.cn/zhengce/zhengceku/2022-10/25/content_5721569.htm

Description: In California, the state legislature can regulate the state licensure requirements. AB 1010 is one example of the legislature creating such training and education requirements. Through AB 1010, which passed in 2021, all licensed architects in the state of California must go through five hours of continuing education every two years (when renewing their license) specifically on the topic of net-zero carbon design.
Source(s): AIA California. (2023, September 23). Net zero carbon continuing education signed into law. AIA California. https://aiacalifornia.org/press-room-releases/net-zero-carbon-continuing-education-signed-into-law/

Description:
Pledge from Canada, Germany, US, and UK (Members of the Industrial Deep Decarbonisation Initiative or IDDI) include the following: 
Level 1: Starting no later than 2025, require disclosure of
the embodied carbonin cement/concrete and steel
procured for public construction projects
Level 2: Starting no later than 2030, conduct whole project life cycle assessments for all public construction projects, and, by 2050, achieve net zero emissions in all public construction projects. 
Level 3: Starting no later than 2030, require procurement of low emission cement/concrete and steel in public
construction projects, applying the highest ambition
possible under national circumstances. 
Level 4: Starting in 2030, require procurement of a share of cement and/or crude steel from near zero emission
material production for signature projects
Target: Net zero emissions in public buildings and/or built infrastructure
Source(s): Industrial Energy Accelerator. (2023). The GPP pledge brochure 2023 update. Industrial Energy Accelerator. https://www.industrialenergyaccelerator.org/wp-content/uploads/FINAL-The-GPP-Pledge-brochure-2023-update.pdf

Title of Policy: Brookline, MA Warrant Article 18 -- Use of Low-carbon Concrete
Description: Resolution passed in Brookline, MA to use low-carbon concrete "wherever feasible" in construction where low-carbon concrete is defined as a product that emits at least 10% less carbon dioxide in its production compared to the average mixture used for a given application
Policy Subcategory: Resolution/Declaration of Intent, Public Sector Incentives
Source(s): Brookline Advisory Committee. (2021, October 13). Advisory committee report WA-18 final. Town of Brookline. https://www.brooklinema.gov/DocumentCenter/View/25813/Advisory-Committee-ReportWA-18final101321?bidId=
